intro: Coriandropsis syriaca, commonly known as the Syrian coriander tree, is a deciduous shrub or small tree native to the Middle East and parts of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes plants like carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its aromatic leaves and small yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, thriving in well-drained soils. Its leaves are used in traditional medicine for their purported anti-inflammatory and digestive properties. The fruit, which resembles a small, dry schizocarp, is also used in some local cuisines.
